Essential Spanish Phrases for Mexico Travel

100+ Useful Words and Phrases to Enhance Your Trip

Last updated: January 2025

While English is widely spoken in Mexican tourist areas, knowing some Spanish will dramatically enhance your experience. Mexicans appreciate any effort to speak their language, and even basic phrases open doors to genuine connections, better service, and experiences beyond the tourist bubble. Here are the essential phrases you'll use every day.

  • Essential Responses

The Basics

{<strong>Greetings & Politeness:</strong></p><ul><li>Hola (OH-lah) — Hello</p><ul><li>Buenos días (BWAY-nohs DEE-ahs) — Good morning</p><ul><li>Buenas tardes (BWAY-nahs TAR-days) — Good afternoon</p><ul><li>Buenas noches (BWAY-nahs NO-chays) — Good evening/night</p><ul><li>Adiós (ah-DYOHS) — Goodbye</p><ul><li>Por favor (por fah-VOR) — Please</p><ul><li>Gracias (GRAH-syahs) — Thank you</p><ul><li>Muchas gracias (MOO-chahs GRAH-syahs) — Thank you very much</p><ul><li>De nada (day NAH-dah) — You're welcome</p><ul><li>Disculpe (dees-KOOL-pay) — Excuse me</p><ul><li>Lo siento (loh SYEN-toh) — I'm sorry</p><ul><li>Con permiso (kohn pair-MEE-soh) — Excuse me (when passing)</p><p><strong>Tip:</strong> 'Buenas' by itself works as a casual greeting any time of day.}

Essential Responses

{<strong>Yes, No & Understanding:</strong></p><ul><li>Sí (see) — Yes</p><ul><li>No (noh) — No</p><ul><li>Tal vez (tahl vays) — Maybe</p><ul><li>Claro (KLAH-roh) — Of course</p><ul><li>Está bien (es-TAH BYEN) — It's okay/fine</p><ul><li>No hay problema (noh eye proh-BLAY-mah) — No problem</p><ul><li>Entiendo (en-TYEN-doh) — I understand</p><ul><li>No entiendo (noh en-TYEN-doh) — I don't understand</p><ul><li>Más despacio, por favor (mahs des-PAH-syoh por fah-VOR) — More slowly, please</p><ul><li>¿Puede repetir? (PWAY-day ray-pay-TEER) — Can you repeat?</p><ul><li>No hablo español (noh AH-bloh es-pahn-YOL) — I don't speak Spanish</p><ul><li>Hablo un poco (AH-bloh oon POH-koh) — I speak a little}

Restaurants & Food

{<strong>At the Restaurant:</strong></p><ul><li>Una mesa para dos (OO-nah MAY-sah PAH-rah dohs) — A table for two</p><ul><li>El menú, por favor (el may-NOO por fah-VOR) — The menu, please</p><ul><li>¿Qué recomienda? (kay ray-kohm-YEN-dah) — What do you recommend?</p><ul><li>Quiero... (KYAIR-oh) — I want...</p><ul><li>Me gustaría... (may goos-tah-REE-ah) — I would like...</p><ul><li>La cuenta, por favor (lah KWEN-tah por fah-VOR) — The check, please</p><ul><li>¿Está incluido el servicio? — Is service included?</p><ul><li>¡Estuvo delicioso! (es-TOO-voh day-lee-SYOH-soh) — It was delicious!</p><p><strong>Food Words:</strong></p><ul><li>Agua (AH-gwah) — Water</p><ul><li>Cerveza (sair-VAY-sah) — Beer</p><ul><li>Vino tinto/blanco (VEE-noh TEEN-toh/BLAHN-koh) — Red/white wine</p><ul><li>Café (kah-FAY) — Coffee</p><ul><li>Pollo (POH-yoh) — Chicken</p><ul><li>Carne (KAR-nay) — Meat/beef</p><ul><li>Pescado (pays-KAH-doh) — Fish</p><ul><li>Mariscos (mah-REES-kohs) — Seafood</p><ul><li>Vegetariano (vay-hay-tah-RYAH-noh) — Vegetarian</p><ul><li>Sin carne (seen KAR-nay) — Without meat</p><ul><li>Picante (pee-KAHN-tay) — Spicy</p><ul><li>No muy picante (noh mwee pee-KAHN-tay) — Not too spicy}

Hotels & Accommodation

{<strong>At the Hotel:</strong></p><ul><li>Tengo una reservación (TEN-goh OO-nah ray-sair-vah-SYON) — I have a reservation</p><ul><li>Una habitación (OO-nah ah-bee-tah-SYON) — A room</p><ul><li>Con cama doble (kohn KAH-mah DOH-blay) — With double bed</p><ul><li>Con dos camas (kohn dohs KAH-mahs) — With two beds</p><ul><li>¿Tiene aire acondicionado? (TYEH-nay AI-ray ah-kohn-dee-syoh-NAH-doh) — Does it have A/C?</p><ul><li>¿A qué hora es el check-out? — What time is check-out?</p><ul><li>¿Tiene WiFi? (TYEH-nay WEE-fee) — Do you have WiFi?</p><ul><li>¿Cuál es la contraseña? (kwahl es lah kohn-trah-SAY-nyah) — What's the password?</p><ul><li>¿Puede llamar un taxi? (PWAY-day yah-MAR oon TAK-see) — Can you call a taxi?</p><ul><li>Llave (YAH-vay) — Key</p><ul><li>Toallas (toh-AH-yahs) — Towels}

Transportation

{<strong>Getting Around:</strong></p><ul><li>¿Dónde está...? (DOHN-day es-TAH) — Where is...?</p><ul><li>¿Cómo llego a...? (KOH-moh YAY-goh ah) — How do I get to...?</p><ul><li>Derecha (day-RAY-chah) — Right</p><ul><li>Izquierda (ees-KYAIR-dah) — Left</p><ul><li>Derecho/Recto (day-RAY-choh/REK-toh) — Straight</p><ul><li>Cerca (SAIR-kah) — Near</p><ul><li>Lejos (LAY-hohs) — Far</p><ul><li>La parada de autobús (lah pah-RAH-dah day ow-toh-BOOS) — The bus stop</p><ul><li>El aeropuerto (el ah-air-oh-PWAIR-toh) — The airport</p><ul><li>La estación de autobuses — The bus station</p><p><strong>Taxis & Uber:</strong></p><ul><li>¿Cuánto cuesta? (KWAHN-toh KWES-tah) — How much does it cost?</p><ul><li>¿Puede llevarme a...? (PWAY-day yay-VAR-may ah) — Can you take me to...?</p><ul><li>Aquí está bien (ah-KEE es-TAH BYEN) — Here is fine (to stop)</p><ul><li>Pare aquí (PAH-ray ah-KEE) — Stop here}

Shopping & Money

{<strong>At Shops & Markets:</strong></p><ul><li>¿Cuánto cuesta? (KWAHN-toh KWES-tah) — How much?</p><ul><li>Es muy caro (es mwee KAH-roh) — It's too expensive</p><ul><li>¿Tiene algo más barato? (TYEH-nay AHL-goh mahs bah-RAH-toh) — Do you have something cheaper?</p><ul><li>Me lo llevo (may loh YAY-voh) — I'll take it</p><ul><li>No, gracias (noh GRAH-syahs) — No, thank you</p><ul><li>Solo estoy viendo (SOH-loh es-TOY VYEH-n-doh) — I'm just looking</p><ul><li>¿Aceptan tarjeta? (ah-SEP-tahn tar-HAY-tah) — Do you accept cards?</p><ul><li>Efectivo (ay-fek-TEE-voh) — Cash</p><ul><li>Cambio (KAHM-byoh) — Change</p><ul><li>Recibo (ray-SEE-boh) — Receipt}

Emergencies

{<strong>Urgent Situations:</strong></p><ul><li>¡Ayuda! (ah-YOO-dah) — Help!</p><ul><li>Emergencia (ay-mair-HEN-syah) — Emergency</p><ul><li>Llame a la policía (YAH-may ah lah poh-lee-SEE-ah) — Call the police</p><ul><li>Necesito un médico (nay-say-SEE-toh oon MAY-dee-koh) — I need a doctor</p><ul><li>¿Dónde está el hospital? — Where is the hospital?</p><ul><li>Me siento mal (may SYEN-toh mahl) — I feel sick</p><ul><li>Me robaron (may roh-BAH-rohn) — I was robbed</p><ul><li>Perdí mi pasaporte (pair-DEE mee pah-sah-POR-tay) — I lost my passport</p><ul><li>¿Dónde está la embajada? — Where is the embassy?</p><ul><li>Estoy alérgico/a a... (es-TOY ah-LAIR-hee-koh ah) — I'm allergic to...}

Numbers

{<strong>Essential Numbers:</strong></p><ul><li>0 - cero (SAY-roh)</p><ul><li>1 - uno (OO-noh)</p><ul><li>2 - dos (dohs)</p><ul><li>3 - tres (trays)</p><ul><li>4 - cuatro (KWAH-troh)</p><ul><li>5 - cinco (SEEN-koh)</p><ul><li>6 - seis (says)</p><ul><li>7 - siete (SYEH-tay)</p><ul><li>8 - ocho (OH-choh)</p><ul><li>9 - nueve (NWAY-vay)</p><ul><li>10 - diez (dyays)</p><ul><li>20 - veinte (VAYN-tay)</p><ul><li>50 - cincuenta (seen-KWEN-tah)</p><ul><li>100 - cien (syen)</p><ul><li>1000 - mil (meel)</p><p><strong>Tip:</strong> For prices, listen for 'pesos' (PAY-sohs). '150 pesos' sounds like 'syen-toh seen-KWEN-tah PAY-sohs.'}

Mexican Slang & Expressions

{<strong>Common Mexican Expressions:</strong></p><ul><li>¿Qué onda? (kay OHN-dah) — What's up? (very casual)</p><ul><li>¿Mande? (MAHN-day) — Pardon? (polite way to ask someone to repeat)</p><ul><li>¡Órale! (OH-rah-lay) — Wow! / Come on! / Okay! (multi-purpose)</p><ul><li>¡Qué padre! (kay PAH-dray) — How cool!</p><ul><li>No hay pedo (noh eye PAY-doh) — No problem (casual/slang)</p><ul><li>Ahorita (ah-oh-REE-tah) — Right now (but could mean later!)</p><ul><li>Güey (way) — Dude (casual, among friends)</p><ul><li>Sale (SAH-lay) — Okay/done/deal</p><ul><li>¡Salud! (sah-LOOD) — Cheers! (when drinking)</p><ul><li>¡Buen provecho! (bwen proh-VEH-choh) — Enjoy your meal!</p><p><strong>Warning:</strong> Some slang can be rude in the wrong context. When in doubt, stick to formal Spanish.}

Pronunciation Tips

{<strong>How to Sound More Natural:</strong></p><p><strong>Vowels are consistent:</strong></p><ul><li>A = 'ah' (as in 'father')</p><ul><li>E = 'eh' (as in 'bed')</p><ul><li>I = 'ee' (as in 'feet')</p><ul><li>O = 'oh' (as in 'go')</p><ul><li>U = 'oo' (as in 'food')</p><p><strong>Consonant differences:</strong></p><ul><li>J = 'h' sound (jalapeño = hah-lah-PEN-yoh)</p><ul><li>LL = 'y' sound (tortilla = tor-TEE-yah)</p><ul><li>Ñ = 'ny' sound (mañana = mah-NYAH-nah)</p><ul><li>H = silent (hola = OH-lah)</p><ul><li>R = slightly rolled, RR = strongly rolled</p><p><strong>Emphasis:</strong> Usually on the second-to-last syllable, unless there's an accent mark.}

Frequently Asked Questions

Do I need to speak Spanish in Mexico?

In tourist areas (Cancún, Playa del Carmen, Los Cabos, resort hotels), English is widely spoken. But even basic Spanish phrases earn you goodwill and often better service. Outside tourist zones, Spanish becomes much more useful—and sometimes necessary.

What's the most important phrase to learn?

'Por favor' (please) and 'gracias' (thank you). Politeness goes a long way in Mexico. Also learn '¿Cuánto cuesta?' (how much?) and 'la cuenta, por favor' (the check, please) for practical daily use.

Is Mexican Spanish different from Spain Spanish?

Yes, but mutually intelligible. Mexican Spanish is generally considered softer and more sing-song. Key differences: Mexicans use 'ustedes' (you plural), not 'vosotros.' Some vocabulary differs (car = 'carro' in Mexico, 'coche' in Spain). Mexicans will understand you either way.

What if I make mistakes?

Make them! Mexicans are incredibly patient and encouraging with language learners. They'll appreciate your effort far more than they'll judge your grammar. Laughter and pointing work when words fail. The worst that happens is a funny misunderstanding.
